Award.AwardTitle: Point Defects and Transport Properties of a Lower Mantle Phase (Mg,Fe)O: The Role of Hydrogen and Ferric Iron
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project, the PI will investigate the nature of point defects and related transport properties in (Mg,Fe)O such as diffusion and electrical conductivity. (Mg,Fe)O is one of the major minerals in the Earth's lower mantle and these properties are key to the understanding of the dynamics of the lower mantle. A particularly important issue is the role of oxidation state and of hydrogen in controlling these properties. A review of existing literature suggests that the role of hydrogen in controlling these properties in (Mg,Fe)O is likely very different and pressure dependent. Through a systematic study of point defect-related properties, the PI and his team will obtain the first data set to understand the transport properties of the largest part of Earth's mantle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project ained at understanding the properties of the lower mantle (the deep part of Earth's interior) particularly the properties such as atomic diffusion and electrical conductivity. The lower mantle of the Earth is the largest portion of Earth and properties of this layer control the major activities of Earth including the rate of mantle convection. These properties of minerals are controlled by tiny "crystalline defects" such as impurities much the same way as the properties of some of the semi-conductirs (such as Si and Ge). The major consituent minerals in this region are silicate perovskite and (Mg,Fe)O. Among them, (Mg,Fe)O is likely to have higher diffusion rates and higher electrtical conductivity and hence plays an imprtant role in many processes of the lower mantle.We have done a detailed experimental and theoretical studies on these properties of (Mg,Fe)O one of the consituent minerals in this region. All the experiments were made using a high-pressure and temperature apparatus in our lab under the carefully controlled conditions inlcuding the control of oxygen fugacity and water content. We found that The results have established a solid model of these defects that will help our understanding of properies and processes in the Earth's deep interior.
